facts.text: Petition No. 9 of 1957 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 9 of 1957. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR J. on December 2, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. December 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-

facts.text: Petitioner was a wholesale and retail dealer in tobacco at Banaras and owned a private bonded warehouse for tobacco and held licences for the same.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was a wholesale and retail dealer in tobacco at Banaras and also owned a private bonded warehouse for tobacco and held licences for the same.

facts.text: Petitioner's warehouse checked by Inspector Das who found some irregularity and sealed the warehouse on December 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners warehouse was checked by Inspector Das who on finding some irregularity sealed the warehouse on December 8, 1953, and subsequently

facts.text: Inspector Das took possession of all registers and stock cards after sealing the warehouse.

anchor.surface_text: sealed the warehouse on December 8, 1953, and subsequently took possession of all the registers and stock cards.

facts.text: On December 22, 1953, 11 1/2 bags of kandi (stems of tobacco) found in petitioner's warehouse were removed by the Inspector and stored elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: On December22,1953, 11 1/2 bags of kandi i.e. stems of tobacco . which were found in the petitioners warehouse, were removed from

facts.text: Petitioner made representations to the Collector against the orders and some correspondence passed.

anchor.surface_text: Against those orders the petitioner made certain representations to the Collector and some correspondence passed.

facts.text: On June 15, 1954, Collector of Central Excise issued notice to petitioner to show cause why penalty for contravention of Rules 151C and 226 and confiscation of kandi bags.

anchor.surface_text: On June 15, 1954, the Collector, Central Excise, issued a notice to the petitioner to show cause why a penalty should be imposed

facts.text: Petitioner showed cause, was heard by Collector, and filed written arguments.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner showed cause, the Collector heard the petitioner who had also filed written arguments.

facts.text: Collector found charges proved, ordered confiscation of kandi bags, imposed fine of Rs. 150 and duty in lieu of confiscation, and penalty of Rs. 2,000 under Rules 151C and 226.

anchor.surface_text: Finding the charges against the petitioner proved, the Collector ordered confiscation of the bags of kandi, imposed a fine of Rs. 150

facts.text: Appeal to Central Board of Revenue dismissed because petitioner refused to deposit penalty of Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal taken to the Central Board of Revenue was dismissed as the petitioner refused to deposit the penalty of Rs. 2,000

facts.text: Revision to Central Board of Revenue dismissed for same reason as appeal (non-deposit of penalty).

anchor.surface_text: and a revision to the Central Board of Revenue was also dismissed for the same reason.

facts.text: On July 29, 1954, Collector called upon petitioner to produce another surety as Mohammad Satar was not prepared to act.

anchor.surface_text: On July 29, 1954, the Collector called upon the petitioner to produce another surety as the previous surety Mohammad Satar

facts.text: Petitioner furnished two bonds in Form B-4 for Rs. 7,000 and B-5 for Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner states that he thereupon furnished two bonds in Form B-4 and B-5 for Rs. 7,000 and Rs. 10,000 respectively.

facts.text: Rs. 15,263-8-0 due from petitioner as excise duty; 373 Mds. of tobacco attached by Excise Department and sold by auction for Rs. 6,878-5-0, leaving balance of Rs. 8,385-3-0.

facts.text: Petitioner filed civil suit in court of First Additional Civil Judge, Banaras; ad-interim injunction issued against Department recovering balance duty.

anchor.surface_text: As the Department made demands for the recovery of this balance of duty the petitioner filed a civil suit in the court

facts.text: On January 25, 1956, Superintendent of Excise called upon petitioner to deposit cash security of Rs. 10,000 or licence treated as cancelled under r. 181(1).

anchor.surface_text: On January 25, 1956, the Superintendent of Excise called upon the petitioner to deposit a cash security of Rs. 10,000

facts.text: Petitioner demurred to cash security demand; outstanding excise duty not paid.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner demurred to this and as the outstanding amount of excise duty was not paid

facts.text: On February 13, 1956, Deputy Collector ordered petitioner's licence to remain inoperative till deposit made.

anchor.surface_text: the Deputy Collector ordered on February 13, 1956, that till the deposit was made the petitioners licence shall remain

facts.text: Appeal against Deputy Collector's order dismissed by Central Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner took an appeal against this order to the Central Board of Revenue which was dismissed.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 226 filed in Punjab High Court and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also filed a petition under Art. 226 in the Punjab High Court which was also dismissed

issues.text: whether the Act in question is a law with respect to the matters enumerated in item 45 of List 1 or to the matters enumerated in item 27 and 29 of List 11. In other words does it, in pith and substance, relate to duties of excise on tobacco as contained in item 45 or it falls within the boundaries of items 27 and 29 of the provincial list and if it falls within the former, is its validity affected by its incidental trespass into the territory reserved for provincial legislation

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is whether the Act in question is a law with respect to the matters enumerated in item 45 of List 1 or to the matters enumerated in item 27 and 29 of List 11. In other words does it, in pith and substance, relate to duties of excise on tobacco as contained in item 45 or it falls within the boundaries of items 27 and 29 of the provincial list

arguments.claim: licence fees are taxation within central competence; bonded warehouses for evasion control

anchor.surface_text: The system of licensing of bonded warehouses was always considered to be a part of effective control of evasion of tax in England and Parliament must be deemed to have contemplated the inclusion of this power. Besides, the levying of licence fees is itself a form of taxation.

holdings.text: the Act was within the legislative competence of the Central legislature and although there may be certain matters otherwise within the legislative competence of the provincial legislature they are necessarily incidental to effective legislation by the Central legislature. The various provisions of the Act and the Rules made thereunder were, in our opinion, essentially connected with the levying collection of excise duty and in its true nature and character the Act remains one that falls under item 45 of List 1 and the incidental trenching upon the provincial field of items 27 or 29 would not affect its constitutionality
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examined scheme, object, pith and substance of Act and Rules; all provisions directed to effective levy and collection of excise on tobacco; incidental provincial matters valid per precedents like Prafulla Kumar, Attorney-General cases.

holdings.text: the Act remains one that falls under item 45 of List 1 and the incidental trenching upon the provincial field of items 27 or 29 would not affect its constitutionality because the extent of invasion of the provincial field may be a circumstance to determine the true pith and substance but once that question is determined the Act, in our opinion, would fall on the side of Central field and not that of the provincial field.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance test applied; substantial part central (excise duty); incidental trespass into provincial list does not invalidate per established doctrine and precedents.

holdings.text: the restrictions imposed were unreasonable and therefore not saved by Art. 19(6). [...] The argument of unreasonable restriction because of this ground must also fail.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions necessary for effective collection; no procedural unfairness as natural justice followed, hence reasonable under Art.19(6).

holdings.text: there is no dispute that in the instant case there was no breach of this rule. Not only this, there is a right of appeal and a revision is also provided and both these remedies the petitioner availed himself of.

anchor.surface_text: If the tribunal is to act judicially it must conform to the principles of natural justice of audi alteram partem and there is no dispute that in the instant case there was no breach of this rule. Not only this, there is a right of appeal and a revision is also provided and both these remedies the petitioner availed himself of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner showed cause, heard, filed arguments; appeals and revisions pursued; principles of audi alteram partem satisfied.

holdings.text: There was no illegal imposition on the petitioner nor is it shown that anything was threatened to be realised without the authority of law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Penalty deposit condition for appeal/revision authorised by law; distinguished Himmatlal as no unauthorised threat or imposition.

holdings.text: The Collector was acting within his powers if he asked for the deposit of cash security of Rs. 10,000.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Surety inefficient; proviso to r.140 empowers demand for fresh/additional/cash security; connected to r.181 powers.
